review_blob: i gave this a try and shouldnt have. it has a nasty aroma of metal coated corn and the taste fully lives up to that. It is sharp and edgy and certainly the worst bock-like brew I had in a long time. Brewed by the Grinch himself to spoil X-Mas.

Danke Benzym! Quite a phenolic Weizen with everything in place. The banana is keept a little outside while the Clove is going all the way! Hazy light golden color and good lasting, thick head, reminds me a lot of Schneiders Original in appearance and aroma. Full mouthfeel, for a  german weizen anyway. Nice

Thanks Benzym for sharing! Probably the darkest Klsch on earth with a fine mix of dark chocolate and coffee, quite a bit of coffee. Very balanced finish, overall quite harmonic with the coffee triumphing in the end, lovely.

Siphon enjoyed with Benzym himself, pours dark golden with a rich and lasting white head, delicate grassy, earthy hop aroma above a subtle malty base. Rather sweet mouthfeel with a very fine balanced fresh hopyness. A perfect Klsch with a drinkability that is out of this world

Bottle, hazy corn golden banana color, actually quite muddy.very fruity bananjuice aroma with hints of orange and lime. Tastes like bananajuice gone wild, and pre-chewed fruitcake. Maybe the drain appreciates it more..
small bottle, dark golden amber, no head really. intense aroma of alcohol mostly syringa, a little clean toffee too. flavor is intense malty on a sweet and rich palate with a short sweet aftertaste,

bottle, color amber gold and no head worth mentioning, no hoparoma, a hint of sulfur, with a little toasted malt. Flavor, yes well uhh hard to find, sweet malt and hop bitterness somewhere in the distance maybe. finishes slighlty bitter and balanced. likeable but easily replaceable

chestnut brown, little, quick disappearing head, fairly inviting, very nice aroma of red fruits, bitter orange, sugar and caramel and cheese. flavor is balanced between sweetness, and dark caramel malts with just a hint of roastiness, that gives a little bitterness. the alcohol is never evident and expertly built in. an inoffensive, balanced and rich brew

bottle, dark brown, almost black with a red hue, nice mocca colored head, looks good. the aroma is very muted, a little milk chocolate and coffee, some hops and a little alcohol. the flavor is very simple, some caramel malt on a coffee and dark chocolate base. spicy and vegi hops and a rough lingering noble hop finish. I find the balance not ok, which is on the hoppy side especially in the finish. Plus it is just to simple of a porter, no dark fruit, molasse, burnt sugars..well, but it is flawless.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Bottle, murky dark red brown color and a little tiny head, that puffs away. aroma is prunes, chocolate and syringa. flavor really complex with dark fruits, milk chocolate a little banana, orange marmalade. The alcohol is evident and a major player in this world class game

bottle, Danke Du ! pours murky, milky orange brown, with a fast disappearing head, not very inviting. Intense aroma of orange peel and that pharmacy smell that coriander tends to give, its good. Flavor gives subdued impressions of coriander and orange peel, very much in balance. I dont pick up much hop in aroma or flavor, niothing wrong with that though. It ends slighlty lactic acidic. Well the acidic notes and bad appearance really make this an average experience.

bottle, hazy red brown beer and almost no head, very secret aroma, but harmonic. The brew really lives from its flavor of chocolate, plum and toffie, very tasty and perfectly balanced, but some roasted notes and just the right amount of bitter hop impressions, which are rather earthy and a little spicy. keeps me sipping

Flasche bienfait of bckstck, golden good lasting head, little subdued hop aroma, no flaws here. Flavor just to muted, the malt taste is good but needs to be enhanced, fruity and spicy hops that increases while the pint wents down. High carbonation gives this brew a rather sour, then sweet impression. this could be nice ,if worked on.

Flasche bienfait of Bckstck, red brown almost clear color, little peach colored head, nothing much to make the tail wag, sweet milky aroma, a little chocolate too but not very enhanced. Flavor is more complex with a little coffee somewhere in between sitting on a rather tenacious palate that is lifted by good carbonation levels. good. flawless but obviously not for schmucks.

Bottle, cherry brown color with a little peach colored head, heavy malty aroma, some roasted notes mainly chocolate, creamy palate all the way that just in the end dries out. very pleasant aroma of brownie, dark chocolate, roasted coffee and fudge, indeed very complex. excellent!
see through bottle, orange golden in color, very clean beer with good amount of skunkyness prsent, low profile with a rather broad lingering bitterness that hangs a little to long. drink and move on

hazy orange with nasty chucks of yeast floating around, that is just off putting. well yeah you figure, big simcoe aroma with its typical pine, grapefruit, mango ,cat-pee impression, good intensity!  flavor reflects the impression, interesting is much more the palate, which is a wired mix of chewiness and fizzyness. a big body dancing over your tongue, like an elephant in ballet shoes hmm, ok balance of malt and bitterness for the style. Seems more like a test brew, then a finished product.

small bottle, hm a large oak impression hits you when sniffing this rather hazy red brown brew, its is combined with a candish sour cherry frutiness and bready notes, along with some vinegar very inviting. the flavor is sharp and very defined with again cherry dominating. intense sourness but the sweet malty body makes a good contrast, ends sweet and sour ,with a little vinegar sour maybe.

bottle, a hazy red amber beer with a small short lasting cream colored head. fresh frutiy aroma, some bubbelgum maybe. the flavor is dominated by a big plastic note, seems to be a fermentation error, without out it could have been decent

Bottle beautyfull red brown color, sour flavors in the nose along with some chocolate. In the mouth it is just outstanding, lactic tart, creamy chocolate, a nice wood impression in the back, lots of sour cheeries, and a bunch of  delicous red wine  in total harmonie with each other. Finish is slighlty tart and so wunderbar cream chocolaty and a litle chalky. Freaking good!

0,75 L bottle, pours cloudy brown with a good head that last for 2 seconds. Dark fruits in the nose, alcohol and little anis, flavor is intense with dark fruits again, big anis note and a rather grainy finish. the palate is very livley, but thin. the finish is grainy again and to rough for my liking although not lasting. alcohol is evident.

bottle, pours balck with a nice little head on top. Grain,liquorize and roast malts in the nose, some dark fruit in the back. Flavor is very elegant grainy again but soft, only little sweet liquorize, dark chocolate, maybe some coffee and notes of prunes. The palate is excellent, perfectly balanced, it glides over the tongue, not at all offensive, short lasting aftertaste with a mineralic finish. I enjoy it a lot !

bottle, pours silently into my glass and i can find no thing that could be mentioned as a head. Hazy dark golden color and no bubbles arise to invite me. Aroma is a delicate summary of fruits, alcohol and caramel and the flavor reflects it pretty much but some spicy hop joins in to wave from a far distance. Very pleasant beer, highly approachable, which sounds better then calling it plain, I guess.

bottle 2007, dense but fast falling mocca head, intense aroma of fruit, highly complex, hard to single out a specific one other then raisins and damsons, flavor is likewise and a cascade of beautyful notes. Intense alcohol impression, but never burning! Smooth dry finish. Very refreshing and luxurus offering indeed.

bottle, smells like a stale dubbel with some roast notes added, not inviting. some more unpleasant dark fruit notes in the flavor before a husky, dry , nasty finish kicks in, that gives the impression of chewing on caraffa, the sharp carbonation gives me the rest. Not impressive at all.

deep black with a red hue, short lasting head, aroma is intense with strong plum fragrance, backed up by coffee and dark chocolate impressions, I am not quite sure if i like the combination by it sure is unique. But it is in the mouth where this brew really performs. It starts out sweet and rich becomes dry and very typical stoutish in the middle and finishes with a ripe fruit notes and again dryes out n the far finish. nice to do this over and over again with every sip. Alcohol is never hot, almost not even warming, excellent!

bottle, pours with a surprisingly short lasting mocca colored head and a deep black beer. lots of chocolate in the nose combined with a fresh fruitiness and a good portion of noble hops, simple but inviting. It develops nicely in the mouth due to the now very obvious fizzyness, nicely dancing on the tongue, releasing flavors of dry chocolate, sherry, beet molasse and fudge. The finish is short ,rather chalked and dry but with a good balance. Overall I only get the fizzyness from a wheat beer, no other thing reminds me of that style. The alcohol is warming but never hot or even burning, excellent! A not very complex but charming beer.

bottle, pours with a short lasting beige head on a beautyfull coffee colored beer with a red hue, aroma of coffee, liquorize and a little dark fruit. surprisingy no alcohol in the nose, excellent!!  The flavor gives gentle impressions of again cafe, liquorize, and ripe dark fruits. the finish is fine balanced by earthy and spicy hop impressions, but to sweet for my liking. A really well made doppelbock from someone, who understands that this style needs time!

This beer pours with a peach colored lasting head on a hazy copper colored beer. You can sit and watch the joyfull dance of tiny bubbles keeping the head stable. The rich aroma of overripe fruits is framed by lilac flowers, lightly toasted malts and a more earthy spicyness. The overripe fruits turn more into a rum soked fruits impression in the mouth, very intense and a well balanced finish. Very nice chrismas beer

bottle, dark unclear chestnut brown in color, almost no head, inviting aroma of dark toasted malts and ripe fruits, a little banan too.taste is likewise with more pronounciation on the dark fruits like prune, damsons and hints of raisins, with hints of caramel and toasted malts, good chewy body, very nice x-mas beer!

bottle, clear, reddish brown in color, no head ,you have to concentrate hard to pick up on the aroma which are alcohol, prunes and some caramel if you have the imagination, flavor offers a little more dark fruit, very watery palate, the best on the brew is the bottle is has been packed in, one to forget

bottle, hazy dark orange marmalade color, fair lasting head. lots of rye bread in the nose, toasted malts and some nektarine. the flavor is pretty much the same, but the beer lives from the finish which is a fine balance of earthy and grassy hops with some darker munich malts flavors, no chrismas in here but it is a  fine lager with slight metal faults

bottle, dark brown with a good lasting cafe latte colored head, alcohol, anis, caramel malt in the nose but on a low lintensity, the flavor is much more powerfull with a lot of prunes and dried figs up front, a sweet prune wine taste in the middle and a rather evident anis finish, body starts out full and rich but finishes medium dry, along there are little coffee and milky notes, i quite like it

Bottle Vintage 2003, cellared at home for 4 years, served at 16 C. When serving it a complex vinous aroma instantly fills the room letting my expectation shoot rocket high. Pours with no head, cristal clear and a most beautyful dark reddish brown color that reminds of dried cherry wood.

The aroma is highly complex but seems to be dominated by beach and oak wood smoke, dates, alsacian munster cheese. In the back I can find a little alcohol, which during the entire tasting never gets warm or even hot, caramel and little roast like the crust of toasted white bread.

The flavor is a harmonius explosion of chewy caramel and toffee, congac soaked figs, butter scotch and I am not talking about diacetyl here, lots of milk chocolate with hazelnut in the finish, so complex yet so harmonius.

On the palate it is rich, oily, highly viscous but never cloying or unpleasently lingering, just perfectIy balanced with hop that hardly shows its present. 

I would not know what to improve in this beauty other then increasing bottle size. I am looking forward to next year to try the 2004...

bottle, one year old, golden color with reddish hue,quite cloudy, quickly disappearing head. aroma is alcohol, a little citric hops and not much else apart a hint of pine. Flavor starts with  stale malt and more sharper hops notes appeare, the bitterness is pleasant though and only lingers shortly.  It kind of misses character, it seems a little undefined, messy, I miss the clear idea with this brew!

bottle,light golden, warm color, rather hazy, thick lasting head, very vage aroma with hints of apple, green strawberry, alcohol and while it warms up slight notes of caramel malts. Full palate with simple caramel malt notes, astringent bitter finish that reminds a little of tobacco, the bitter finish is a little harsh and could be smoother and less lingering. Otherwise really nice.

bottle, perfectly clear mahagony color, fastly disappearing white head, aroma is surprisingly gentle, a little light cane melasse, no alcohol, beaten white of egg and a hint of strawberry, flavor is again unbelievable gentle, more light  caramel in the mouth, melasse with a touch of salty  liquorize, quite straight forward. the mouthfeel is initial sweet until a well balanced bitterness kicks in at last. respect to make a high gravity lager taste so gentle, extra points for that!!!

bottle, nice chestnut brown color, thick creamy light brown foam, quite inviting. aroma is dominated by alcohol notes, spice cookies made from cinnemon, cane sugar with a touch of melasse, a little sweet liquorize lies over it all, hmm yammie. Flavor reminds me of chrismas cookies again, its just the liquorize that turned into anis, juicy dates join into the dance and gentle raisin notes great from above. the palate is initially quite sweet, full and chewy, while the finish is balanced by earthy hop notes to an almost perfect balance. another sip just to starts this trip all over hmm

from ferkins at the EBF, foggy orange mist in a glass, inviting hoppy aroma with notes of tropical peach, mango and fresh oranges, fantastic taste lots of fresh tropical fruit impressions, balancing bitter finish, a little ornage and mandarine on the palate, little sour astringent, just fantastic, I hope it will be available on bottle

bottle, milky cloudy light orange color, thick and mostly lasting head..fragrance is subtle herbs, very little banana and more evident clove..inital mouthfeel is herbal again, a litte spice going over to a more sweettish impression and finishing with a delicat bitterness, which kind of saves the beer. Overall I find aroma and flavor a bit muted. Yeasty flavor are under controll but it just lacks freshness. A little less malt flavor and more pronounced fermentation 
byproducts would do this beer good. A bit better then average.

bottle, creamy head on a beautyful colored beer, dark orange, reddish highlights, perfectly clear..the fragrance is vinious with notes of raisin, fresh powerful hop invites you to taste it..flavor of delicious creamy caramel, bitter orange marmalade, impressive clean, pleasant and benevolent bitterness, lingers only shortly to make place for a long burnt caramel finish. Especially the balance between malty sweetness and bitterness is excellent.

Bottle chilled at 5 C poured into an orval gllass First impression is a hazy golden beer with fast disappearing head foam. Aroma is full of banana and yeast with a hint of malt sweetness and alchohol. Taste starts of gentle with a nice mouth feel of sweetness before the low carbon dioxide starts dancing on the tongue releasing all the spicy notes of fruit in the form of "bitter orange marmalade" and clove taste from the yeast. A little pepper feel as well. All of which is enhance by the alcohol warming feel. All these flavors continue beautifully in a lingering aftertaste of contemptment. Needs to be drunk quickly before the temperature raises and all these flavors are lost leaving only a strong alcohol taste.

served from tap at the bryghus. dark amber color with shiny red highlights, brownish at the corners.  sweet malty notes leaning towards caramel and sweet bread. strong impressive flavor with a wide range of different caramel notes, little toasted, really tasty. long sweet aftertaste with a well balance hop impression, with little earthy and spicy notes. i fully enjoyed it, excellent!!

bottle at 5 C, very small head on a cloudy pinkish beer, fragrance of raspberry, spicy yeast, a little pepper and gum, astringent mouthfeel, not as creamy as wits are. the palate improves with the beer warming up and the fizzyness decreasing! Aftertaste is dominated by  delicate red fruits impressions, quite dry or better brut! A little warming alcohol. Nice balance but actually a low profile beer.

Bottle bought as a supposebly treat for myself, promising aroma of a decent stout, delicous coffee and acoholic powerful nose. the first impression in the mouth is again coffee, then hot alcohol numbs the mouth and everything vanishes from there. the finish is then just muted, dry, offensiv and disappointing. a little sweet liquirish lingers as an sorry excuse. this beer should have been stored much longer before its release, it just thems unfinished, green and raw. At a better price i would buy another one and cellar it.
beer_name: Amager Danish Beerhouse Barrel Aged Series Imperial Stout

review_blob: Bottle,  a reddish black beer with a nice dense and lasting foam, dark fruit aroma, probably from oxidation, again notes of prune and sherry but subtle, a good deal of sweet liquorize in taste and no real roastiness, so it is probably just colored with roast malt extract, anyway, it works fine here! Medium dry finish, good hop and malt balance. A little cooked corn (DMS) in the background though, otherwise a decent brew!!

Bottle, a hazy amber color with red hue, short lasting head. strong oxidation flavor leading to dark fruits with prune and sherry. Quite a sweet sticky palate, especially for a wheat, strong caramel sweetness and a rather pleasant bitter finish. the strangest wheat beer I ever had, i wonder how much of this was intended!

long lasting, dense white foam on a amber, golden cloudy beer. fruity nose, strong aroma of rye bread, little banana in the back overall lies a simple acidity. creamy, sticky sweet palate, munich malty long sweet aftertaste. rather heavy body for the style. simple weizenbier missing the zesty gusto!

Bottle: Nice beautyful nut color and a dense foam, just after opening the bottle I could pick up fresh hop in my kitchen. Piney, citrusy hop notes, not to complex, little alcohol here in the smell too. Opens gently in the mouth. Notes of grapefruit, damsons and cooked bread, little chocolate in the aftertaste. Long pleasant bitter finish, flawless!! Well done, easy to recommend!

Long lasting foam with small bubbles on an light amber, hazy looking beer. Aroma of bubble gum, grapefruit, phenols and a slight staleness. Taste of Grapefruit, red orange and bitter orange marmalade, dry mouthfeel with a lingering pinelike bitterness, not so pleasant, taste a little stale again. Hmm american hops and wit seems to be an interesting combination, if just the pine like bitterness was brought under control. But the tropical fruit and wit works great together!! I enjoyed it..
